name: Hypericin
summary: A naturally occurring compound in St. John's Wort, studied for antidepressant and antiviral properties.
description: Hypericin is a naphthodianthrone compound found in the plant *Hypericum perforatum* (St. John's Wort). It has been investigated for its potential antidepressant effects, thought to involve modulation of neurotransmitter systems and inhibition of monoamine oxidase. It also has photodynamic and antiviral properties, though clinical use is mainly as part of herbal preparations for mild to moderate depression.

contraindications: Concurrent use with strong serotonergic drugs (risk of serotonin syndrome)
Pregnancy unless advised by a clinician

sections.text: May inhibit reuptake of serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine; also modulates GABA and glutamate receptors; exhibits weak monoamine oxidase inhibition.

adult.depression: Typically 300 mg of standardized extract (0.3% hypericin) three times daily

sections.geriatric: Same as adult dosing; monitor for drug interactions

sections.text: Antidepressant effect may be seen within 2–4 weeks; full effect by 6–8 weeks.

serious: serotonin syndrome (when combined with other serotonergic drugs)

other: Strong inducer of CYP3A4 and P-glycoprotein—may reduce effectiveness of many drugs
Avoid with other antidepressants without medical supervision

sections.pregnancy: Not recommended due to limited safety data

sections.text: No physiological withdrawal expected, but gradual discontinuation may help monitor for symptom return.

items: Best evidence supports use for mild to moderate depression
Standardization to hypericin content is important for consistent effect
Not FDA-approved as a prescription drug in the U.S.
